raw.author: Virchow
contexts: The Celts, if I may make a parenthetic statement, were throughout a blonde race; and it is wrong to connect, as Virchow still connects, those traces of an essentially dark-haired population which are to be seen on the more elaborate ethnographical maps of Germany with any Celtic ancestry or with any admixture of Celtic blood: in this context it is rather the pre-Aryan population of Germany which surges up to these districts.
commentaries: The author disputes Virchow's ethnographical connection of dark-haired populations in Germany with Celtic ancestry, arguing instead for a pre-Aryan origin.

goodreads_match.title: The Will to Power
goodreads_match.description:
Nietzsche's notebooks, kept by him during his most productive years, offer a fascinating glimpse into the workshop and mind of a great thinker, and compare favorably with the notebooks of . The Will to Power, compiled from the notebooks, is one of the most famous books of the past hundred years, but few have studied it. Here, at last, is the first critical edition in any language.
Down through the Nazi period The Will to Powerwas often mistakenly considered to be Nietzsche's crowning systematic labor; sinc...

raw.author: Goethe
contexts: makes itself a bad science in the 'labyrinth of the breast,' to use Goethe's phrase
the most subtle and brilliant spirits, such as Goethe, such as Hafiz, have even seen in this a further charm of life.
Homer would not have created an Achilles, nor Goethe a Faust, if Homer had been an Achilles or if Goethe had been a Faust.
Goethe has maintained that there are only thirty-six tragic situations: we would infer from that, did we not know otherwise, that Goethe was no ascetic priest.
one must have a higher conception of Mephistopheles than Goethe had, who found it necessary to diminish his Mephistopheles in order to magnify his 'inner Faust.'
commentaries: The author quotes Goethe's phrase to metaphorically describe the internal, tortuous workings of the bad conscience within the individual.
The author references Goethe as an example of a brilliant spirit who viewed the balance between sensuality and chastity as a charm of life, not a tragic conflict.
The author references Goethe as another example of an artist whose creative work (Faust) is distinct from his own personal reality, supporting a general thesis about artistic separation.
The author references Goethe's assertion about the limited number of tragic situations, using it to contrast Goethe's perspective with that of an ascetic priest.
The author critiques Goethe's portrayal of Mephistopheles in Faust, arguing it was diminished to elevate the character of Faust.

raw.author: Renan

raw.author: Immanuel Kant
contexts: Kant thought that he showed honour to art when he favoured and placed in the foreground those of the predicates of the beautiful, which constitute the honour of knowledge: impersonality and universality.
I need only mention Plato, Spinoza, La Rochefoucauld, and Kant—four minds as mutually different as is possible, but united on one point; their contempt of pity.

By the bye, even in the Kantian idea of "the intellegible character of things" there remains a trace of that schism, so dear to the heart of the ascetic, that schism which likes to turn reason against reason; in fact, "intelligible character" means in Kant a kind of quality in things of which the intellect comprehends this much, that for it, the intellect, it is absolutely incomprehensible.
with regard to the humiliating and deteriorating effect of which Kant has made a remarkable confession, 'it annihilates my own importance'
Kant for the derivation of his Categorical Imperative, his own belief certainly not having come to him from this source.
commentaries: The author references Kant's philosophical ideas on beauty, critiquing his definition of the beautiful as that which pleases without interest.
The author cites Kant as one of several historical philosophers unanimously holding a contempt for pity, in contrast to the modern exaggerated estimation of it.

The author critiques Kant's concept of the 'intelligible character of things' as an example of the ascetic tendency to set reason against itself, viewing it as a remnant of ascetic ideology in philosophy.
The author cites Kant's personal confession about astronomy's effect on human self-importance as an example of science fostering contempt for humanity.
The author questions the origins of Kant's Categorical Imperative, suggesting it did not arise from the reasoning Kant presented.

raw.author: Schopenhauer
contexts: I had to place myself in a state of abstraction, in which I was almost alone with my great teacher Schopenhauer

So, for example, did Richard Wagner take, "when the time had come," the philosopher Schopenhauer for his covering man in front, for his rampart. Who would consider it even thinkable, that he would have had the courage for an ascetic ideal, without the support afforded him by the philosophy of Schopenhauer, without the authority of Schopenhauer, which dominated Europe in the seventies?

Let us now apply this interpretation to gauge correctly the case of Schopenhauer, which we have already mentioned: in his case, the sight of the beautiful acted manifestly like a resolving irritant on the chief power of his nature (the power of contemplation and of intense penetration); so that this strength exploded and became suddenly master of his consciousness.
commentaries: The author references Schopenhauer as his great teacher, whose ideas on the value of 'un-egoistic' instincts like pity he engaged with and fundamentally opposed, seeing them as a danger and a symptom of decline.
The author argues that Wagner relied on Schopenhauer's philosophy as a protective authority to justify his turn toward ascetic ideals in his later work.
The author discusses Schopenhauer's aesthetic theory, specifically his response to beauty, to critique and expand upon the relationship between sensuality and the aesthetic state.

goodreads_match.title: Beyond Good and Evil
goodreads_match.description: In Beyond Good and Evil, Nietzsche accuses past philosophers of lacking critical sense and blindly accepting dogmatic premises in their consideration of morality. Specifically, he accuses them of founding grand metaphysical systems upon the faith that the good man is the opposite of the evil man, rather than just a different expression of the same basic impulses that find more direct expression in the evil man. The work moves into the realm "beyond good and evil" in the sense of leaving behind the tradition...

goodreads_match.title: Ethics
goodreads_match.description:
A profoundly beautiful and uniquely insightful description of the universe, Benedict de Spinoza's Ethics is one of the masterpieces of Enlightenment-era philosophy. This Penguin Classics edition is edited and translated from the Latin by Edwin Curley, with an introduction by Stuart Hampshire.
Published shortly after his death, the Ethicsis undoubtedly Spinoza's greatest work - an elegant, fully cohesive cosmology derived from first principles, providing a coherent picture of reality, and a guide to the mean...

raw.title: Old Testament
raw.author: Unknown
contexts: The Old Testament—yes, that is something quite different, all honour to the Old Testament! I find therein great men, an heroic landscape, and one of the rarest phenomena in the world, the incomparable naïveté of the strong heart; further still, I find a people.
commentaries: The author praises the Old Testament for its heroic qualities, strong characters, and the portrayal of a people, contrasting it favorably with the New Testament.

raw.title: New Testament
raw.author: Unknown
contexts: I do not like the 'New Testament'; it almost upsets me that I stand so isolated in my taste so far as concerns this valued, this over-valued Scripture; the taste of two thousand years is against me; but what boots it!
commentaries: The author criticizes the New Testament as an overvalued scripture, expressing a strong personal dislike for its content and style, and positioning himself against two millennia of prevailing taste.

raw.author: Plato
contexts: I need only mention Plato, Spinoza, La Rochefoucauld, and Kant—four minds as mutually different as is possible, but united on one point; their contempt of pity.
or a petty subconscious enmity and rancour against Christianity (and Plato), that has conceivably never crossed the threshold of consciousness?

Up to the present what great philosophers have been married? Heracleitus, Plato, Descartes, Spinoza, Leibnitz, Kant, Schopenhauer—they were not married, and, further, one cannot imagine them as married.
Such, e.g., was the Greek; Plato shows it in a hundred places, Plato, who knew his contemporaries—and himself.
The real lie, the genuine, determined, "honest" lie (on whose value you can listen to Plato) would prove too tough and strong an article for them by a long way
from that Christian belief, which was also Plato's belief, the belief that God is truth, that truth is divine....
Plato's instinct felt this––Plato, the greatest enemy of art which Europe has produced up to the present.
Thucydides' morals are the same as those that exploded everywhere with Plato.
we would condemn Plato for his pia fraus
commentaries: The author cites Plato as one of several historical philosophers unanimously holding a contempt for pity, in contrast to the modern exaggerated estimation of it.
The author mentions Plato as a possible target of subconscious enmity among English psychologists, grouping him with Christianity as an object of resentment.
The author includes Plato in a list of unmarried philosophers to argue that marriage is typically incompatible with the philosophical life.
The author references Plato as an authority on the nature of Greek oligarchies and their internal tensions.
The author cites Plato's concept of the 'honest lie' as a philosophical standard against which modern dishonesty is measured.
The author references Plato as holding a belief that truth is divine, linking him to the Christian metaphysical tradition that underpins the ascetic ideal.
The author references Plato as an intellectual figure whose instinct recognized art's fundamental opposition to the ascetic ideal, positioning him as art's greatest enemy.
The author cites Plato's moral influence, noting its widespread impact in contrast to other historical periods.
The author criticizes Plato for employing pious fraud, indicating a negative judgment on his philosophical methods.

raw.author: Epicurus
contexts: "This is the painless state which Epicurus praised as the highest good and as the state of the gods; we are during that moment freed from the vile pressure of the will, we celebrate the Sabbath of the will's hard labour, the wheel of Ixion stands still."
commentaries: The author notes that Schopenhauer, in his writing, references Epicurus's praise of the painless state as the highest good, linking it to the aesthetic state.

raw.author: Leibnitz
contexts: Up to the present what great philosophers have been married? Heracleitus, Plato, Descartes, Spinoza, Leibnitz, Kant, Schopenhauer—they were not married, and, further, one cannot imagine them as married.
commentaries: The author references Leibnitz among other philosophers who were not married, supporting the idea that marriage is a hindrance to philosophical achievement.

raw.author: Buckle
contexts: The extent of the mischief which is caused by this prejudice (once it is free of all trammels except those of its own malice), particularly to Ethics and History, is shown by the notorious case of Buckle: it was in Buckle that that plebeianism of the modern spirit, which is of English origin, broke out once again from its malignant soil with all the violence of a slimy volcano, and with that salted, rampant, and vulgar eloquence with which up to the present time all volcanoes have spoken.
commentaries: The author criticizes Buckle as a notorious example of the detrimental influence of democratic prejudice on ethics and history, associating him with a plebeian and vulgar modern spirit.

raw.author: Heracleitus
contexts: Henceforth man is to be counted as one of the most unexpected and sensational lucky shots in the game of the 'big baby' of Heracleitus, whether he be called Zeus or Chance

Up to the present what great philosophers have been married? Heracleitus, Plato, Descartes, Spinoza, Leibnitz, Kant, Schopenhauer—they were not married, and, further, one cannot imagine them as married.
I grant that when Heracleitus retreated to the courts and cloisters of the colossal temple of Artemis, that "wilderness" was worthier; why do we lack such temples?
commentaries: The author references Heracleitus's philosophical concept of play or chance to describe man's emergence as a fortuitous accident in the cosmos.
The author lists Heracleitus among philosophers who were not married, using this to support the idea that marriage is a hindrance to the philosophical optimum.
The author references Heracleitus as a historical example of a philosopher who sought solitude in a temple, illustrating the ideal conditions for philosophical thought.

raw.title: Joyful Wisdom
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
contexts: and here I quote my Joyful Wisdom, cp. Book V. Aph. 344: "The man who is truthful in that daring and extreme fashion, which is the presupposition of the faith in science, asserts thereby a different world from that of life, nature, and history; and in so far as he asserts the existence of that different world, come, must he not similarly repudiate its counterpart, this world, our world?"

(If this seems too laconically expressed, I recommend the reader to peruse again that passage from the Joyful Wisdom which bears the title, "How far we also are still pious," Aph. 344, and best of all the whole fifth book of that work, as well as the Preface to The Dawn of Day.)
The answer stands in my Joyful Wisdom, Aph. 357
commentaries: The author quotes directly from his own book, 'Joyful Wisdom', to support his argument about the metaphysical belief underlying science.
The author references his book 'Joyful Wisdom' and its specific aphorism, suggesting the reader consult it for further elaboration on the critique of truth's value.
The author cites a specific aphorism from his own earlier book to answer the question of what triumphed over the Christian God.

goodreads_match.title: The Dawn of Day
goodreads_match.description: When Nietzsche called his book The Dawn of Day, he was far from giving it a merely fanciful title to attract the attention of that large section of the public which judges books by their titles rather than by their contents. The Dawn of Day represents, figuratively, the dawn of Nietzsche's own philosophy. Hitherto he had been considerably influenced in his outlook, if not in his actual thoughts, by Schopenhauer, Wagner, and perhaps also Comte. Human, all-too-Human, belongs to a period of transition. After h...

raw.author: Pascal
contexts: as far as the intellect is concerned, Pascal's principle, "il faut s'abêtir."
commentaries: The author references Pascal's principle as an example of a method to reduce consciousness and combat depression, placing it within a discussion of ascetic practices.

raw.author: Feuerbach
contexts: Just remember with what enthusiasm Wagner followed in the footsteps of Feuerbach. Feuerbach's motto of "healthy sensuality" rang in the ears of Wagner during the thirties and forties of the century, as it did in the ears of many Germans (they dubbed themselves "Young Germans"), like the word of redemption.
commentaries: The author references Feuerbach as an intellectual influence on Wagner, specifically noting his motto of 'healthy sensuality' as a guiding principle Wagner initially embraced.

raw.author: Sebastian Bach
contexts: as Sebastian Bach has testified in undying and outrageous words in the dedication of his High Mass
commentaries: The author cites Bach's dedication of his High Mass as an example of the slavish humility of artists to their public.

raw.author: Herbert Spencer
contexts: How much more logical is that contrary theory (it is not the truer for that) which is represented, for instance, by Herbert Spencer, who places the concept "good" as essentially similar to the concept "useful," "purposive," so that in the judgments "good" and "bad" mankind is simply summarising and investing with a sanction its unforgotten and unforgettable experiences concerning the "useful-purposive" and the "mischievous-non-purposive."
life itself has been defined (by Herbert Spencer) as an increasingly effective internal adaptation to external circumstances.
commentaries: The author references Herbert Spencer's theory that equates 'good' with 'useful' and 'purposive', presenting it as a coherent but incorrect alternative explanation for the origin of moral judgments.
The author cites Herbert Spencer's definition of life as an example of a theory that fails to grasp the essence of life as a will to power, critiquing it as a product of modern misarchism.

raw.author: Thucydides
contexts: Thucydides' morals are the same as those that exploded everywhere with Plato.
commentaries: The author references Thucydides' moral views, comparing them to those of Plato, as part of a discussion on historical moral systems.

raw.author: Spinoza
contexts: I need only mention Plato, Spinoza, La Rochefoucauld, and Kant—four minds as mutually different as is possible, but united on one point; their contempt of pity.
when he actually made as a matter of principle 'disinterested malice' (or, to use Spinoza's expression, the sympathia malevolens) into a normal characteristic of man

This truth came insidiously enough to the consciousness of Spinoza (to the disgust of his commentators, who (like Kuno Fischer, for instance) give themselves no end of trouble to misunderstand him on this point), when one afternoon (as he sat raking up who knows what memory) he indulged in the question of what was really left for him personally of the celebrated morsus conscientiæ—Spinoza, who had relegated "good and evil" to the sphere of human imagination, and indignantly defended the honour of his "free" God against those blasphemers who affirmed that God did everything sub ratione boni ("but this was tantamount to subordinating God to fate, and would really be the greatest of all absurdities").

Up to the present what great philosophers have been married? Heracleitus, Plato, Descartes, Spinoza, Leibnitz, Kant, Schopenhauer—they were not married, and, further, one cannot imagine them as married.
commentaries: The author cites Spinoza as one of several historical philosophers unanimously holding a contempt for pity, in contrast to the modern exaggerated estimation of it.
The author references Spinoza's concept of 'sympathia malevolens' (malevolent sympathy) to describe a primal, disinterested cruelty in mankind.

The author references Spinoza's philosophical views on good and evil and the concept of conscience, using him as an example of a thinker who understood punishment and guilt in a non-moralistic, fatalistic manner.
The author cites Spinoza as part of a list of philosophers who remained unmarried, illustrating the philosopher's shudder at marriage.

raw.title: Don Quixote
raw.author: Miguel de Cervantes
contexts: (The reader will perhaps remember Don Quixote at the court of the Duchess: we read nowadays the whole of Don Quixote with a bitter taste in the mouth, almost with a sensation of torture, a fact which would appear very strange and very incomprehensible to the author and his contemporaries—they read it with the best conscience in the world as the gayest of books; they almost died with laughing at it.)
commentaries: The author contrasts the modern reader's pained reaction to the cruelty in 'Don Quixote' with the original audience's perception of it as a purely humorous work.

goodreads_match.title: Don Quixote
goodreads_match.description: Don Quixotehas become so entranced by reading chivalric romances, that he determines to become a knight-errant himself. In the company of his faithful squire, Sancho Panza, his exploits blossom in all sorts of wonderful ways. While Quixote's fancy often leads him astray - he tilts at windmills, imagining them to be giants - Sancho acquires cunning and a certain sagacity. Sane madman and wise fool, they roam the world together, and together they have haunted readers' imaginations for nearly four hundred year...

raw.author: Hafiz
contexts: the most subtle and brilliant spirits, such as Goethe, such as Hafiz, have even seen in this a further charm of life.
commentaries: The author references Hafiz alongside Goethe as an example of a brilliant spirit who found charm in the balance between sensuality and chastity.

raw.title: Human, all-too-Human, a Book for Free Minds
raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
contexts: in that collection of aphorisms entitled Human, all-too-Human, a Book for Free Minds
commentaries: The author references his own earlier work as the first expression of his thoughts on the genealogy of moral prejudices.

goodreads_match.title: Human, All Too Human: A Book for Free Spirits
goodreads_match.description: A collection of aphorisms by Friedrich Nietzsche, marking his transition to a more critical and analytical philosophical style, divided into nine sections covering various topics including metaphysics, morality, and art.

raw.title: Course of Philosophy
raw.author: E. Dühring
contexts: (E. Dühring, Value of Life; Course of Philosophy, and passim.)
commentaries: The author references this book alongside 'Value of Life' to illustrate Dühring's philosophical arguments, which he opposes regarding the basis of justice in reactive feelings.

goodreads_match.title: Cursus der Philosophie als streng wissenschaftlicher Weltanschauung und Lebensgestaltung
goodreads_match.description: Dühring's major philosophical work presenting his system of philosophy, which Friedrich Nietzsche critiques in 'On the Genealogy of Morals'. The work is commonly referred to as 'Course of Philosophy' in English translations.

raw.title: The Origin of the Moral Emotions
raw.author: Paul Rée
contexts: The title of the book was The Origin of the Moral Emotions; its author, Dr. Paul Rée; the year of its appearance, 1877.
commentaries: The author identifies this book as the direct impulse for publishing his own hypotheses on morality, describing it as a clear, well-written, and precocious work that presented a perverse moral philosophy antithetical to his own ideas, which attracted him magnetically.

goodreads_match.title: Der Ursprung der moralischen Empfindungen
goodreads_match.description: A philosophical work by Paul Rée that argues morality originates from social utility rather than divine command or reason. It influenced Nietzsche's thinking on morality.
